choices: A 29-year-old man who received the hepatitis B vaccine last week
A 21-year-old woman who had her nose pierced last week
A 30-year-old man who lived in Zambia for 3 years and returned last month
A 54-year-old man who tested positive for hepatitis C last year but has no active symptoms of disease

correctAnswer.answer: A 29-year-old man who received the hepatitis B vaccine last week
correctAnswer.explanation: If the donor is symptom free, there is no deferral period for the hepatitis B vaccine. Persons who have had body piercing are given a 12-month deferral. Persons who lived in an area endemic for malaria or who received antimalarial drugs are deferred for 3 years. A positive test for the hepatitis C virus (HCV) is cause for indefinite deferral.

data.question: Which of the following individuals is acceptable as a blood donor?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/2

choices: Yes
No, she is on warfarin
Yes, for RBCs only
No, her hemoglobin is too low

correctAnswer.answer: Yes, for RBCs only
correctAnswer.explanation: Her age and hemoglobin meet donor criteria. However, because she is currently on warfarin, only RBCs can be prepared from her donation.

data.question: SITUATION: A 53-year-old woman donates blood at her place of employment. She weighs 150 lb and has a hemoglobin level of 13 g/dL. She is currently on warfarin and vitamin B12. Is she an acceptable donor?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/2

choices: Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG)
Rubella vaccine
Influenza vaccine
Yellow fever vaccine

correctAnswer.answer: Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG)
correctAnswer.explanation: Deferral for HBIG injection is 12 months. Deferral for rubella vaccine is 4 weeks. The deferral period for influenza and yellow fever vaccines is 2 weeks.

data.question: Which immunization has the longest deferral period?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/1

choices: A 40-year-old woman who last donated on July 23
A 28-year-old man who had plateletpheresis on August 24
A 52-year-old man who made an autologous donation on September 9
A 23-year-old woman who donated blood for her aunt on August 14

correctAnswer.answer: A 28-year-old man who had plateletpheresis on August 24
correctAnswer.explanation: A plateletpheresis donor must wait at least 48 hours between donations. The waiting period following an autologous donation is at least 3 days. An 8-week interval must pass between all other types of donations.

data.question: The following whole blood donors regularly give blood. Which donor may donate on September 10?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/2

choices: Platelet count of 75 × 109/L in a donor who is a frequent platelet donor
Plasma loss of 800 mL from plasmapheresis 1 week ago
Plateletpheresis performed 4 days ago
Aspirin ingested 7 days ago

correctAnswer.answer: Platelet count of 75 × 109/L in a donor who is a frequent platelet donor
correctAnswer.explanation: To be eligible for plateletpheresis, the platelet count should be greater than 150 × 109/L for a frequent platelet donor. Plasma loss exceeding 1,000 mL would be cause for rejection, but not 800 mL. A donor may donate 24 times a year, but not as frequent as once every 2 days in a 7-day period. A donor cannot ingest aspirin within 36 hours of platelet donation.

data.question: Which of the following precludes acceptance of a plateletpheresis donor?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/1

choices: A construction worker who was incarcerated for opiate abuse
A triathlete with a pulse of 45
A man who is currently taking finasteride (Propecia)
A woman in her 14th week of pregnancy

correctAnswer.answer: A triathlete with a pulse of 45
correctAnswer.explanation: Athletes may have a pulse below 50 and may still be acceptable as blood donors. Drug addiction is cause for permanent deferral, as is a major illness. The deferral period after treatment for syphilis or gonorrhea is 12 months.

data.question: Which of the following donors could be accepted for whole blood donation?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/2

choices: Weight of 105 lb
Pulse of 75
Temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F)
Diastolic pressure of 110 mm Hg

correctAnswer.answer: Diastolic pressure of 110 mm Hg
correctAnswer.explanation: Diastolic pressure must not be higher than 100 mm Hg. Donors weighing less than 110 lb may donate up to 12% of their blood volume (volume = weight in kg/50 × 450 mL). Oral temperature must not be greater than 37.4°C (99.5°F). BP limits for donation are 180 mm Hg for systolic and 100 mm Hg for diastolic pressure. The limit for hemoglobin is 12.5 g/dL and for hematocrit 38%.

data.question: Which physical examination result is cause for rejecting a whole blood donor?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/1

choices: Male donor whose father has been diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)
Donation of a unit of blood that transmitted hepatitis B virus (HBV) to a recipient
Donor tested reactive for HBV by nucleic acid testing (NAT)
Accidental needlestick 1 year ago; negative for infectious disease

correctAnswer.answer: Accidental needlestick 1 year ago; negative for infectious disease
correctAnswer.explanation: An accidental needlestick would not be a cause for indefinite deferral of a donor. The deferral period is 1 year.

data.question: Which situation is not a cause for indefinite deferral of a donor?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor requirements/1

choices: Platelets
RBCs
FFP
Cryoprecipitate

correctAnswer.answer: Platelets
correctAnswer.explanation: Clopidogrel (Plavix) renders platelets nonfunctional, and therefore potential donors on this medication cannot donate platelets.

data.question: A whole blood donor currently on clopidogrel (Plavix) is precluded from donating which product?
data.reference: Blood bank/Select course of action/Donor processing/Unacceptable donors/1

choices: 12 mL
15 mL
20 mL
23 mL

correctAnswer.answer: 12 mL
correctAnswer.explanation: To determine the amount of anticoagulant to remove when the donor is less than 110 lb, divide weight by 110 lb, and multiply by 450 mL; divide that number by 100, and multiply by 14 (this gives the anticoagulant volume needed); then subtract this from 63 mL, which is the standard volume of anticoagulant in a 450 mL bag. The result is the amount of anticoagulant to remove.

data.question: How much anticoagulant would have to be removed from the collection bag given a donor who weighs 90 lb?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donor collection/2

choices: Continue the donation; rapid breathing is not a reason to discontinue a donation
Withdraw the needle, raise her feet, and administer ammonia
Discontinue the donation, and provide a paper bag for donor to breathe slowly into
Tell her to sit upright, and apply a cold compress to her forehead

correctAnswer.answer: Discontinue the donation, and provide a paper bag for donor to breathe slowly into
correctAnswer.explanation: This woman is hyperventilating; therefore, the donation should be discontinued. A paper bag should be provided to the donor to breathe into to increase the carbon dioxide in the donor’s air.

data.question: A woman begins to breathe rapidly while donating blood. Choose the correct course of action.
data.reference: Blood bank/Select course of action/Donor processing/Donor adverse reactions/3

choices: Closely observe the bag for at least 3 minutes; if blood flow does not resume, withdraw the needle
Remove the needle immediately, and discontinue the donation
Check and reposition the needle, if necessary; if blood flow does not resume, withdraw the needle
Withdraw the needle, and perform a second venipuncture in the other arm

correctAnswer.answer: Check and reposition the needle, if necessary; if blood flow does not resume, withdraw the needle
correctAnswer.explanation: If blood flow has stopped, check the needle first. If blood flow does not resume after repositioning, then withdraw the needle and discontinue the donation. Do not perform a second venipuncture on the donor.

data.question: A donor bag is half filled during donation when the blood flow stops. Select the correct course of action.
data.reference: Blood bank/Select course of action/Collection/3

choices: A 45-year-old man who is having elective surgery in 2 weeks; he has alloanti-k
A 23-year-old female patient with leukemia and a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dL
A 12-year-old boy who has hemophilia
A 53-year-old woman who has septicemia

correctAnswer.answer: A 45-year-old man who is having elective surgery in 2 weeks; he has alloanti-k
correctAnswer.explanation: The 45-year-old man with alloanti-k is the best candidate for predeposit autologous donation because compatible blood will be hard to find if he needs blood after surgery. The other candidates may not be good choices for donation because the process may prove harmful to them.

data.question: Who is the best candidate for a predeposit autologous donation?
data.reference: Blood bank/Select course of action/Donor processing/Autologous donation/2

choices: Yes, he or she can donate up to 72 hours before surgery
No, he or she cannot donate within 7 days of surgery
Yes, he or she can donate, but only a half a unit
No, he or she cannot donate within 5 days of surgery

correctAnswer.answer: Yes, he or she can donate up to 72 hours before surgery
correctAnswer.explanation: An autologous donor can donate up to 72 hours before expected surgery.

data.question: Can an autologous donor donate blood on Monday if he or she is having surgery on Friday?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Autologous donation/2

choices: 33 minutes
25 minutes
20 minutes
13 minutes

correctAnswer.answer: 13 minutes
correctAnswer.explanation: A unit of whole blood should be collected within 15 minutes.

data.question: Which of the following is an acceptable time in which a unit of whole blood is collected?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Collection/1

choices: One or more units of blood are withdrawn from the patient and replaced with FFP
Units removed may be stored in the operating room at room temperature for 8 hours
Units removed may be stored in the operating room at room temperature for 24 hours
Unused units can be added to the general donor blood inventory

correctAnswer.answer: Units removed may be stored in the operating room at room temperature for 8 hours
correctAnswer.explanation: In acute normovolemic hemodilution, one or more units of blood are removed from the donor and replaced with crystalloid or colloid. Blood may be stored at room temperature for up to 8 hours or at 1°C to 6°C for up to 24 hours. Bleeding during surgery results in less RBC loss after hemodilution, and the autologous RBCs are infused after bleeding stops. Such units are for autologous transfusion only.

data.question: Which of the following is true regarding acute normovolemic hemodilution?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Autologous donation/2

choices: The hematocrit must be at least 38%
The weight for a female is at least 150 lb
The height for a male is at least 5 ft 1 in
The deferral period following collection is 16 weeks

correctAnswer.answer: The hematocrit must be at least 38%
correctAnswer.explanation: The minimum hematocrit for a double RBC donation is 40%.

data.question: All of the following apply to a double RBC unit apheresis collection except:
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Apheresis/1

choices: Discard the unit
Make the unit available for transfusion
Confirm the name with the donor, have admissions make the correction in the computer system, and then make the unit available for transfusion

Ensure that social security numbers match, confirm the name with the donor and have admissions make the correction in the computer system with the medical director’s approval, and then make the unit available for transfusion

correctAnswer.answer: Ensure that social security numbers match, confirm the name with the donor and have admissions make the correction in the computer system with the medical director’s approval, and then make the unit available for transfusion
correctAnswer.explanation: This is a common scenario with women who have recently married, and have not changed their license or other form of identification given to the collection facility. Checking that other demographic information matches is sufficient, if approved by the medical director, because an autologous unit is very difficult to replace in time for surgery.

data.question: An autologous unit of whole blood was collected on a 33-year-old woman in preparation for a knee replacement procedure in 3 weeks. The whole blood unit had her hyphenated last name, first name, and last four digits of her social security number for identification. The laboratory computer system, however, only had her married name and first name, medical record number, and social security number. What should be done with this blood product?
data.reference: Blood bank/Standard operating procedures/Autologous donation/3

choices: 14 years
15 years
16 years
17 years

correctAnswer.answer: 16 years
correctAnswer.explanation: In most states, the youngest age a person can donate is 16 years with parental permission.

data.question: What is the youngest age a person can make allogeneic whole blood donation?
data.reference: Blood bank/Apply knowledge of standard operating procedures/Donation/1

choices: A man who had sex with another man 2 weeks ago
A male construction worker who tested positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)
A man who had sex with another man 2 years ago
A female who had sex with a male who had sex with another male (MSM) 1 month ago

correctAnswer.answer: A man who had sex with another man 2 years ago
correctAnswer.explanation: Men who have sex with men can donate blood if they have not had sex with another man in the past year.
